columns.text: In this exercise, we are given some information about a particular set of bonds. We are then asked to determine the time left, in years, until the bonds mature.

We'll start by summarizing the information given in the problem statement:


**Table 1**. Summary of the information given in the problem statement. |**Variable** | **Value** | |:--:|:--:| | Annual coupon payments (*C*)| 8% | | Yield to maturity (*YTM*) | 7.2% | | Current yield | 7.55%|

Now, before diving into the calculations, we'll go over the most important concepts related to the given information.

- The coupon (*C*) refers to the regular interest payments carried out every year.

- The face value of the bonds (*F*) is the amount that will be repaid at the end of the bonds' time to maturity (*t*).

- The yield to maturity (*YTM*) is the discount rate that makes the total promised bond payments equal the bonds' market price.

- The current yield is equal to the coupon amount (*C*) expressed as a percentage of the bonds' current value.

Next, we'll analyze the relationship between the bond's current value, yield to maturity, coupon, and face value. From this analysis, we should be able to determine their time to maturity *t*. 

The relationship between the previously mentioned variables is expressed in the following equation:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Bond value} &= \text{PV of the annuities} + \text{PV of the face amount}\\[0.5em]
&= \sum_{i = 1}^t \dfrac{C}{(1+YTM)^i} + \dfrac{F}{(1+YTM)^t}\\[2em]
&= \dfrac{C}{YTM}\left( 1 - \dfrac{1}{(1+YTM)^t} \right) + \dfrac{F}{(1+YTM)^t}\\[0.5em]
\end{align*}
$$

Now, on the other hand, we know that the current yield is the percentage amount of the coupon (*C*) divided by the bonds' value, therefore:
$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Current yield} &= \dfrac{C}{\text{Bond value}}\cdot 100\\[1.5em]
\implies \quad \text{Bond value} &= \dfrac{C}{\text{Current yield}}\cdot 100
\end{align*}
$$
In this task, **we have to calculate how many years are left from the Excel Corp. bond.**

When the exercise is missing the face value, assume it is \$1,000. First of all, we should determine the present value of the bond. As we can see, we have given a hint in the exercise. It says current yields are 7.55\%. We do not need to calculate the future cash flow to get the bond price, but we can divide the coupon value by the current yield.

Let's first calculate the coupon value. Coupon rates are determined by the entity that issues a bond. The coupon value will be the same for every future payment. So it is a fixed amount.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{coupon value}=&\text{coupon rate}\times\text{time value}\\[15pt]
&=8\%\times\$1,000\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$80}
\end{aligned}$$

**The coupon value is \$80.**

Now, let's calculate the current price of the bond by using the current yield value and the value of the coupon.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{current price}&=\dfrac{\text{coupon value}}{\text{current yield}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$80}{7.55\%}\\[15pt]
&=\$1,059.60
\end{aligned}$$

**The current price of the bond is \$1,059.60. In the following calculation, we will mark it as a present value.**

Now, let's use the formula for calculating the price of the bond.

$$\text{Price}=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{-n}}{\text{YTM}}+\dfrac{\text{P}}{\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{n}}$$

C-coupon of the bond 

YTM-yield to maturity

P-par value

n-time
